# restrictedROC

restrictedROC calculates restricted ROC curves, their permutation
p-values, plots and multivariate random forest models with restriction.

## Installation

You can install the latest version of restrictedROC like so:

``` r
devtools::install_github("ggrlab/restrictedROC")
```

## Quickstart

Given a dataset with one dependent (outcome, binary) variable and one
independent (predictor, numeric) variables, e.g. the value of a
biomarker in two groups of patients, we want to know if the biomarker is
informative for the outcome.

``` r
set.seed(123)
biodata <- data.frame(
    outcome = factor(c(rep("Good", 50), rep("Poor", 50))),
    biomarker = c(rnorm(50, 10, 3), rnorm(50, 9, 1))
)
head(biodata)
#>   outcome biomarker
#> 1    Good  8.318573
#> 2    Good  9.309468
#> 3    Good 14.676125
#> 4    Good 10.211525
#> 5    Good 10.387863
#> 6    Good 15.145195
```

Here we use `outcome` and `biomarker` as dependent and independent
variables, respectively. `outcome` is a factor with two levels,
`biomarker` is a numeric variable.

The most convenient usage of restrictedROC is via the
[`rROC()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/rROC.md)
function. The most important results of
[`restrictedROC::rROC()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/rROC.md)
are:

- (restricted) AUCs for all possible cutoffs of the predictor variable
- A global and maximal (including all restrictions) AUC
- Permutation p-values for the global and maximal AUC

``` r
# library(restrictedROC)
set.seed(412)
res_rroc <- restrictedROC::rROC(
    x = biodata$biomarker,
    y = biodata$outcome,
    positive_label = "Good",
    n_permutations = 100 # increase that in real data!
)
#> Wed Dec  6 14:06:24 2023      y x ( 1 )
```

`res_rroc` is a nested list where the first level contains all dependent
variables (Here only `y`). The second level contains the results for
each independent variable (here only `x`).

Each dependent + independent variable combination has the following
results:

- `plots`: Plots, only if enabled, otherwise NA
- `permutation`: A `restrictedROC` class element containing each
  permutation result

``` r
single_result <- res_rroc[["y"]][["x"]][["permutation"]]
```

Given a dataframe, you can use arbitrary dependent and independent
variables (within the dataframe) and calculate the restricted ROC curve
for each combination. Additionally, the list names will be set to the
respective dependent (first level) and independent (second level)
variable names.

``` r
set.seed(412)
res_rroc <- restrictedROC::rROC(
    x = biodata,
    dependent_vars = c("outcome"),
    independent_vars = c("biomarker"),
    positive_label = "Good",
    n_permutations = 100 # increase that in real data!
)
#> Wed Dec  6 14:06:26 2023      outcome biomarker ( 1 )
```

``` r
single_result <- res_rroc[["outcome"]][["biomarker"]][["permutation"]]
```

`single_result$permutation_pval` refers to the permutation p-values of:

- `pval.twoside.global`: The global AUC when all samples are used. This
  is the usually known AUC with a calculated permutation p-value.
- `pval.twoside.max`: This is the maximal (restricted or unrestricted)
  AUC’s permutation p-value.

``` r
print(round(single_result$permutation_pval, 3))
#>    pval.twoside.max pval.twoside.global      n_permutations 
#>               0.010               0.069             100.000
```

In this particular example we see that at a significance level of 0.05,
the global AUC is insignificant, but the maximal AUC is significant.
This tells that the data should be restricted and has a **limited
informative range**.

`single_result$global` refers to the AUC, its variance under H0, the
standardized AUC, and its (asymptotic, not permutation!) p-value when
using all samples without restriction.

``` r
print(single_result$global)
#>      auc auc_var_H0   rzAUC pval_asym
#> 1 0.6016     0.6016 1.75103 0.0799407
```

We see that the AUC is 0.6016, with a p-value of 0.08. This is not
significant at a significance level of 0.05.

`single_result$max_total` refers to the AUC, its variance under H0, the
standardized AUC, its (asymptotic, not permutation!) p-value, the
threshold(=restriction value) and which part of the data is **kept** and
therefore **within the informative range**.

``` r
print(single_result$max_total)
#>         auc  auc_var_H0    rzAUC    pval_asym threshold part
#> 1 0.9089069 0.007759784 4.641941 3.451517e-06  9.377944 high
```

In this example, the maximal AUC is 0.9089, with a restriction value of
9.377944 and a focus on the “low” part. Therefore, the informative range
is `biomarker < 9.378`.

In particular, we observe that the AUC is much higher than the global
AUC, and that the p-value is lower. This is because the data is
restricted to the informative range and the AUC is calculated only on
the samples with values within this range.

We have a convenient way to visualize the data and the results:

``` r
grouped_data <- split(biodata$biomarker, biodata$outcome)
png("man/figures/example.png", width = 800, height = 800, res = 120)
print(
    restrictedROC::plot_density_rROC_empirical(
        values_grouped = grouped_data,
        positive_label = "Good"
    )
)
#> $plots
#> 
#> $single_rROC
#> $performances
#> # A tibble: 101 × 21
#>    threshold auc_high positives_high negatives_high scaling_high auc_var_H0_high
#>        <dbl>    <dbl>          <dbl>          <dbl>        <dbl>           <dbl>
#>  1   -Inf       0.602             50             50         1            0.00337
#>  2      4.52    0.614             49             50         1.02         0.00340
#>  3      5.57    0.627             48             50         1.04         0.00344
#>  4      6.20    0.64              47             50         1.06         0.00348
#>  5      6.40    0.654             46             50         1.09         0.00351
#>  6      6.61    0.668             45             50         1.11         0.00356
#>  7      6.66    0.684             44             50         1.14         0.00360
#>  8      6.74    0.677             44             49         1.16         0.00363
#>  9      6.86    0.693             43             49         1.19         0.00368
#> 10      7.19    0.709             42             49         1.21         0.00373
#> # ℹ 91 more rows
#> # ℹ 15 more variables: rzAUC_high <dbl>, pval_asym_onesided_high <dbl>,
#> #   pval_asym_high <dbl>, auc_low <dbl>, positives_low <dbl>,
#> #   negatives_low <dbl>, scaling_low <dbl>, auc_var_H0_low <dbl>,
#> #   rzAUC_low <dbl>, pval_asym_onesided_low <dbl>, pval_asym_low <dbl>,
#> #   tp <dbl>, fp <dbl>, tpr_global <dbl>, fpr_global <dbl>
#> 
#> $global
#>      auc auc_var_H0   rzAUC pval_asym
#> 1 0.6016     0.6016 1.75103 0.0799407
#> 
#> $keep_highs
#>         auc  auc_var_H0    rzAUC    pval_asym threshold
#> 1 0.9089069 0.007759784 4.641941 3.451517e-06  9.377944
#> 
#> $keep_lows
#>         auc  auc_var_H0     rzAUC  pval_asym threshold
#> 1 0.2492063 0.006878307 -3.023958 0.00249491  9.306498
#> 
#> $max_total
#>         auc  auc_var_H0    rzAUC    pval_asym threshold part
#> 1 0.9089069 0.007759784 4.641941 3.451517e-06  9.377944 high
#> 
#> $positive_label
#> [1] "Good"
#> 
#> $pROC_full
#> 
#> Call:
#> roc.default(response = true_pred_df[["true"]], predictor = true_pred_df[["pred"]],     levels = c(FALSE, TRUE), direction = direction)
#> 
#> Data: true_pred_df[["pred"]] in 50 controls (true_pred_df[["true"]] FALSE) < 50 cases (true_pred_df[["true"]] TRUE).
#> Area under the curve: 0.6016
#> 
#> attr(,"class")
#> [1] "restrictedROC" "list"
dev.off()
#> png 
#>   2
```

![aSAH rROC example](reference/figures/example.png)

aSAH rROC example

[`plot_density_rROC_empirical()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_density_rROC_empirical.md)
effectively:

1.  Calls `simple_rROC` to perform restriction
2.  Makes the results readable with
    [`simple_rROC_interpret()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/simple_rROC_interpret.md)
3.  Plots the original data and the restriction results

# Package index

## All functions

- [`apply_restriction()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/apply_restriction.md)
  : Apply a (nested list) of rROC results to new data

- [`default_part_colors`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/default_part_colors.md)
  : This code here defines global variables for the package
  restrictedROC

- [`generate_density_values()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/generate_density_values.md)
  : Generate values for given densities

- [`melt_gendata()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/melt_gendata.md)
  : Melt generated data

- [`merge_applied()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/merge_applied.md)
  : Merge (cbind) applied rROC results

- [`perf_ROC()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/perf_ROC.md)
  : Performance of ROC curves

- [`perf_pROC()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/perf_pROC.md)
  : Performance ROC curves (pROC)

- [`plot_ROC_cdf()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_ROC_cdf.md)
  : ROC curve for given cumulative distribution functions

- [`plot_ROC_theoretical()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_ROC_theoretical.md)
  : ROC curve for positive cumulative distribution and negative quantile
  function

- [`plot_density_ROC()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_density_ROC.md)
  : Plot density + ROC

- [`plot_density_ROC_empirical()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_density_ROC_empirical.md)
  : Plot density + ROC

- [`plot_density_ROC_str()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_density_ROC_str.md)
  :

  Plot density + ROC based on stats::\_

- [`plot_density_empirical()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_density_empirical.md)
  : Plot empirical densities kernel estimate

- [`plot_density_rROC_empirical()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_density_rROC_empirical.md)
  : Plot 4 rROC plots

- [`plot_distributions_2()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_distributions_2.md)
  : Plot exactly 2 distributions

- [`plot_distributions_multiple()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_distributions_multiple.md)
  : Plot multiple (usually \>2) distributions

- [`plot_rROC()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_rROC.md)
  : plot ROC including AUC significance

- [`plot_rROC_joint()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_rROC_joint.md)
  : Plot ROC curve with rzAUC values inside

- [`plot_rROC_part()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_rROC_part.md)
  : Plot (restricted) ROC curves

- [`plot_rROC_single()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_rROC_single.md)
  : plot ROC including AUC significance

- [`plot_rROC_theoretical()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_rROC_theoretical.md)
  : Plot (restricted) ROC curves for theoretic distributions

- [`plot_rzAUCs()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/plot_rzAUCs.md)
  : Plot rzAUC vs FPR

- [`predict(`*`<restrictedROC>`*`)`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/predict.restrictedROC.md)
  : S3 class predict for class "restrictedROC"

- [`predict_rROC_h2o()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/predict_rROC_h2o.md)
  : Predict new data with a trained model

- [`prepare_modeldata()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/prepare_modeldata.md)
  : Prepare model data

- [`prepare_modeldata(`*`<data.frame>`*`)`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/prepare_modeldata.data.frame.md)
  : Prepare model data

- [`rROC()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/rROC.md) :
  Restriction for multiple dependent and independent variables

- [`rROC(`*`<data.frame>`*`)`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/rROC.data.frame.md)
  : Restriction for multiple dependent and independent variables

- [`rROC(`*`<matrix>`*`)`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/rROC.matrix.md)
  : rROC on a matrix of (samples x features)

- [`rROC(`*`<numeric>`*`)`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/rROC.numeric.md)
  : rROC on a single numeric vector

- [`sim()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/sim.md) :
  Simulate values from distributions

- [`simple_rROC()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/simple_rROC.md)
  : restricted ROC

- [`simple_rROC_interpret()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/simple_rROC_interpret.md)
  : restricted ROC interpretation

- [`simple_rROC_permutation()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/simple_rROC_permutation.md)
  : restricted ROC

- [`summary(`*`<rROC>`*`)`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/summary.rROC.md)
  : Give a summary of a rROC() result

- [`train_rROC_h2o()`](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/reference/train_rROC_h2o.md)
  : Train a predictive model using (rROC-preprocessed) data

# Articles

### All vignettes

- [AUROC, Mann-Whitney U and Wilcoxon
  rank-sum](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/articles/examples_01_AUROC_TESTS.md):
- [Paper 01: ROC
  curves](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/articles/paper_01_roccurves.md):
- [Paper 02: rROC
  theoretic](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/articles/paper_02_rROC_theoretic.md):
- [Paper 03: rROC
  partROCs](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/articles/paper_03_rROC_partROCs.md):
- [Paper 04: rROC theoretic with
  FPR](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/articles/paper_04_rROC_theoretic_FPR.md):
- [Paper 05: rROC with varying
  mean/variance](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/articles/paper_05_varying_mean_variance.md):
- [Paper 06: rROC
  scaling/recalculating](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/articles/paper_06_rROC_scaling_vs_recalculate.md):
- [Paper 07: rROC label
  swap](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/articles/paper_07_rROC_twoway.md):
- [Paper 08: rROC
  permutation](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/articles/paper_08_rROC_permutation_bias.md):
- [Paper 09: rROC
  concept](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/articles/paper_09_cartoon_fig2.md):
- [Vignette 01: rzAUC
  colors](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/articles/vignette_01_rzAUC_colors.md):
- [Vignette 02: Restriction
  plots](https://ggrlab.github.io/restrictedROC/articles/vignette_02_restriction_plots.md):
